Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Forging Trans-Pacific Partnerships to Investigate Terrestrial Transitions in Tropical Land Crabs
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how organisms utilize genetic variation to adapt to new habitats is an open question in evolutionary biology. Land crabs are a group that have repeatedly colonized terrestrial habitats, yet little is currently known about the underlying genetic machinery that has led to the impressive physical and physiological adaptations that have allowed them to live successfully on land. This project will connect the researcher with one of the world?s leading authorities on land crab biology, Professor Peter Ng at the National University of Singapore (NUS), and also with leading researchers in the field of crustacean evolutionary biology at the mid-year meeting of The Crustacean Society (TCS). The researcher will examine crabs housed in the collections at the Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum (LKCNHM), and will collaborate with Prof. Ng and his research group to learn about the biology and taxonomy of the crabs. The results from this project will serve as a solid foundation for a larger research project that seeks to further understand one of the most important life-history transitions in biology.

For her dissertation work, the researcher plans to explore the mechanisms underlying the marine-to-terrestrial transition exhibited by brachyuran land crabs by integrating taxonomy, phylogenetics, and next-generation sequencing technologies, but prior to undertaking this larger project, she will first construct a solid taxonomic and systematic understanding of the group. For EAPSI, the researcher will be trained in these topics under the guidance of the world?s leading authority in crab systematics, Prof. Peter Ng at the NUS. She will examine and collect DNA subsamples from the land crab specimens preserved at the LKCNHM, which houses one of the largest collection of preserved land crabs in the world. Additionally, she will present at the mid-year meeting of TCS and network with other carcinologists to form additional international collaborations and partnerships.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the National Research Foundation of Singapore.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transitions from sea to land with or without freshwater intermediaries are exceptionally rare, and they require extraordinary physiological adaptations. Indeed, astonishingly few marine groups have successfully colonized terrestrial habitats. Of these successful groups, brachyuran crabs have colonized terrestrial environments independently at least ten times, representing one of the most dramatic life-history evolution stories in extant marine organisms. Brachyuran land crabs exhibit a gradient of terrestrial adaptations: some families live intertidally and spend only short periods of time out of water, while others live up to several kilometers inland and only seasonally return to the ocean en masse to hatch eggs that then undergo normal larval development. Some families of land crabs have even become so adapted to their new terrestrial environments that they no longer need to return to the sea, not even to breed or shed fertilized eggs.

No matter where they exist on this spectrum, the crabs have all successfully overcome significant evolutionary challenges and evolved solutions to the dramatic physical differences between living in the ocean and living on land. Although a great deal is now understood about the shifts in physiology, metabolism, and morphology that accompany the transitions from sea to land, virtually nothing is known about the genetic basis of these impressive phenotypic and behavioral changes. At a time when human-induced climate change is shifting marine and terrestrial habitats perhaps more rapidly than many organisms can adapt, understanding the mechanics behind rapid evolutionary change could allow us to predict how at-risk populations will respond to dramatic changes in the environment while also informing basic questions about adaptive predictability in evolutionary biology.

In order to obtain the foundational knowledge of the species that I required to complete my dissertation research, for EAPSI, I proposed to work alongside Professor Peter Ng, who is an internationally recognized authority on crab systematics and taxonomy, and is currently both the Director of the Lee Kong Chian Natural History Museum (formerly the Raffles Museum of Biodiversity Research) and a professor in Biological Sciences at the National University of Singapore.

During the funding period, I: 1) learned the taxonomy and systematics of the crab lineages that I plan to study throughout my dissertation using the most comprehensive collections in the world at the at the LKCNHM; (2) collected DNA subsamples from recently collected ethanol-preserved specimens for future phylogenetic analyses; and (3) established collaborations and professional networks with internationally leading carcinologists both at the NUS and at the mid-year meeting of the Crustacean Society to facilitate future field-based expeditions in this region.

Armed with the expertise, genetic samples, and international collaborative network I acquired from the EAPSI Fellowship, I am well-poised to complete a dissertation that may be critical to our understanding of the predictability of evolution, the nature and evolution of adaptive traits in natural systems, and may also provide insight into how life originally evolved on land many millennia ago.
